data.question: What is the surface area of bio-MOF-100?
What strategy is introduced for constructing mesoporous MOFs in the article?
data.answer: Constructing large metal-organic vertices instead of metal-carboxylate cluster vertices.

data.question: Is bio-MOF-100 exclusively mesoporous?
What is the crystal density of bio-MOF-100?
Does increasing the size and complexity of linkers always lead to higher porosity in MOFs?
What is the pore volume of bio-MOF-100?
What method was used to activate bio-MOF-100 for gas adsorption studies?
data.answer: Supercritical CO2 exchange and subsequent evacuation.

data.question: Is the zinc-adeninate building unit (ZABU) larger than the basic zinc-carboxylate cluster?
What is the role of dimethylammonium cations in bio-MOF-100?
data.answer: They reside in the pores to balance the charge.

data.question: Did the use of longer and complex linkers always result in higher porosity for MOFs?
What is the underlying network topology of bio-MOF-100?
What is the calculated free volume percentage of bio-MOF-100?
Does bio-MOF-100 exhibit both micro- and mesopores?
What is the main advantage of using metal-organic building units as vertices for constructing MOFs?
What is the expected outcome of using larger vertices in MOF construction?
data.answer: Increase in pore dimensions without using large, exotic linker molecules.

data.question: Is the structure of bio-MOF-100 interpenetrated?
What is the role of BPDC linkers in bio-MOF-100?
data.answer: They connect each cage to four neighbouring cages.

data.question: Does bio-MOF-100 have the largest MOF pore volume reported to date?
What is the significance of the zinc-adeninate building units in the construction of bio-MOF-100?
data.answer: They serve as discrete metal-organic vertices for the construction of the framework.

data.question: What is the main limitation of using increasingly longer and complex linkers to increase pore metrics in MOFs?
data.answer: Longer linkers often lead to high degrees of interpenetration and consequently low degrees of porosity.
